  The Early Show | CBS Evening News | 48 Hours
    | 60 Minutes | The Saturday Early Show | CBS Sunday
    Morning | Face The
    Nation 















Hi everyone,
 
Officials arrested and charged six men in New Jersey today,
  claiming the suspects are “Islamic militants” who were plotting
  to attack one of the country’s largest Army bases. According to
  authorities, the six men planned to “kill as many soldiers as
  possible” at Fort Dix Army Base in Northern New
   Jersey. Correspondent Bob Orr will have the main story and our
  investigative correspondent Armen Keteyian will look at previous alleged
  terror plots that have been uncovered by authorities here at home.
 
Also at the top of the broadcast, rivers are rising
  in the Midwest. They are swelling to the
  brink in Missouri, Kansas
  and Oklahoma
  today, raising fears that local flooding there will grow more widespread.
  Cynthia Bowers will survey the situation while Nancy Cordes will explain
  exactly how the Midwest’s geography
  makes it so susceptible to flooding. 
 
Much of the water accumulation now threatening the
  center of the country is due to the storm system that spawned the tornadoes
  that leveled Greensburg, Kansas. Hari Sreenivasan is in Greensburg tracking the
  recovery effort.
 
In North
    Carolina, doctors are refusing to participate in
  death-row executions saying that by doing so they violate the
  physician’s oath. Doctors say it is their right and duty not to
  participate in executions. But some prosecutors say that’s just not the
  case and that doctors shouldn’t be able to overrule the justice system.
  Randall Pinkston will cover the debate.
 
Some of the smallest victims of the war in Iraq
  go largely unnoticed, though there are thousands of them. The orphans of Iraq
  often live on the city’s violent streets if they cannot find a place in
  one of the eight cramped orphanages. Our Mark Strassmann will introduce you
  to some Iraqi kids who navigate daily danger alone.
 
Finally, headgear with pizzazz has become a
  signature of Great Britain’s
  royal family. Mark Phillips will take a look at the hats that are fit for a
  queen – Queen Elizabeth II. 
 
I hope you’ll join us,
 




Katie Couric
CouricandCo@cbs.com
